cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Hydraulic action (coasts)
cards.back: Waves force air into cracks in rocks/cliffs, increasing pressure and widening cracks.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Abrasion (coasts)
cards.back: Waves throw rock fragments against cliffs, wearing them away (like sandpaper).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Corrosion / solution (coasts)
cards.back: Seawater dissolves some rock, helping to enlarge hollows and pools.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Cave → arch → stack: why do caves start?
cards.back: Headlands are often cracked/jointed; hydraulic action widens cracks until a cave forms.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Cave → arch → stack: how does an arch form?
cards.back: Continued erosion (e.g., abrasion) enlarges the cave until it breaks through the headland.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Cave → arch → stack: how does a stack form?
cards.back: The arch roof becomes unsupported and collapses, leaving an isolated pillar (stack).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: What is a stump?
cards.back: A stack that has collapsed/decreased in size due to continued wave attack.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Wave-cut notch: how does it form?
cards.back: Hydraulic action and abrasion cut into the cliff base, creating a notch.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Wave-cut platform: how does it form?
cards.back: Notch undercuts the cliff; rock above collapses; repeated erosion leaves a gently sloping platform exposed at low tide (abrasion + corrosion keep lowering it).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Headlands and bays: why do they form?
cards.back: Bands of hard and soft rock along the coast erode at different rates (differential erosion).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Headlands and bays: what happens to soft rock?
cards.back: Soft rock erodes faster, creating a bay; eroded material can speed up erosion by abrasion.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Headlands and bays: what happens to hard rock?
cards.back: Hard rock withstands erosion better, so it is left jutting out as a headland.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Bays: why are beaches common there?
cards.back: Lower energy and more shelter encourages deposition, forming a beach.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Longshore drift: why do waves move sediment along a beach?
cards.back: Waves approach at an angle (often ~45°) due to prevailing wind; swash moves material up the beach at that angle.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Longshore drift: swash vs backwash
cards.back: Swash moves material up the beach in the wave direction; backwash flows straight back down the beach due to gravity.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Longshore drift: overall movement
cards.back: A zig-zag transport of sediment along the coast caused by angled swash and straight backwash.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Spit: what starts it?
cards.back: Longshore drift transports sand/shingle along a coast towards a change in direction.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Spit: why does it build outwards?
cards.back: At a change in coastline direction, sediment is deposited in sheltered water, building a spit out from the land.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Spit: why can it curve (recurved end)?
cards.back: Winds/waves from a different direction push the end inwards, curving it.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Spit: why can’t it always cross an estuary?
cards.back: A river’s flow carries material out to sea, limiting growth across the channel.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Spit: what forms in the sheltered water behind it?
cards.back: Salt marshes can develop in the sheltered water behind the spit.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Bar: how is it different from a spit?
cards.back: A bar forms when a spit grows right across a bay (often where there is no river to carry sediment out to sea).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Bar: lagoon
cards.back: A lagoon is usually found on the landward side of a bar and may fill over time to form a salt marsh.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Bar: another way it can form
cards.back: A sand bank offshore can be moved landwards by waves until it joins the mainland.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Tombolo
cards.back: A depositional feature where a spit links the mainland to an island.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Coast diagrams from memory: exam tip
cards.back: Use simple sketches: headline the feature, then label 3–5 processes/steps clearly.
